Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: General Frameworks for Approximation and Fixed-Parameter Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research develops general frameworks for efficient graph algorithms, which allow to solve entire categories of computational problems all at once. The PIs aim for a general theory of algorithms, wherein a given problem of interest can simply be adapted into the general approach. This approach differs from the traditional study of algorithms, which often focuses on individual solutions to specific problems.

The type of computational graph problems the PIs consider are "optimization problems", where the task is to find a solution whose cost, quality, size, profit, energy, or speed is as large or as small as possible. Most interesting graph optimization problems are NP-hard, essentially implying that there are no efficient algorithms to find the very best solution. This research considers the two main types of algorithms for solving NP-hard graph optimization problems. Approximation algorithms allow the result to be a small factor away from the optimal, but still require a fast running time. Fixed-parameter algorithms allow the running time to be exponential, but confine that exponentiality to a (typically small) parameter other than the problem size, while requiring an optimal solution.

The type of graphs the PIs consider include planar graphs, which can be drawn in two dimensions without any edges crossing each other, and nearly planar graphs such as graphs of bounded genus and graphs excluding a fixed minor. Many graphs of practical interest---for example, computer networks and road networks, which are "drawn" on Earth---are planar or nearly planar. In these settings, the PIs aim to develop general frameworks for approximation and fixed-parameter algorithms.

Intellectual Merit. In this research, the type of computational graph problems the PIs consider are "optimization problems", where the task is to find a solution whose cost, quality, size, profit, energy, or speed is as large or as small as possible. Most interesting graph optimization problems are NP-hard, essentially implying that there are no efficient algorithms to find the very best solution. This research considers the two main types of algorithms for solving NP-hard graph optimization problems. Approximation algorithms allow the result to be a small factor away from the optimal, but still require a fast running time. Fixed-parameter algorithms allow the running time to be exponential, but confine that exponentiality to a (typically small) parameter other than the problem size, while requiring an optimal solution.The funds from this project have supported partially the work of thePI, as well as his 16 Ph.D. students (9 graduated already), 2 Master students (with thesis), 5 Post-docs and one long-term Ph.D. student visitors. The PI and his groupmembers were very successful (e.g., our group has four papers that will appear in the upcoming SODA'18) by publishing at least 55papers on the topics of this project (including 18 journal papersand 37 conference papers). You may see the reports for this year and the past year for the list of papers.

Broader Impacts. The PI co-organizedworkshops on bidimensionality at FOCS and Dagstuhl both in 2013, andthe 2011 Workshop on Approximation Techniques at PrincetonUniversity and will co-organize the 9th Flexible Network DesignWorkshop at UMD in the summer of 2018. The PI has also been the mainorganizer of Capital Area Theory Seminar (CATS) at UMD since 2010. Talks and travels of well-known speakers on topics of this project are supported in part by this grant (as mentioned on the website).In recognition of the PI's work, he has received several awardsduring the period of this project in particular European Associationfor Theoretical Computer Science (EATCS) Nerode Prize, 2015 (for his Bidimensionality theory), the University of Maryland Graduate Faculty Mentor of the YearAward, 2015, and ONR Young Investigator Award, 2011. The PI wasChair of Program Committee for SPAA'17 as well (in addition toserving in numerous other conference PCs as well as editorial boardsof journals). The PI has been the coach of the University ofMaryland ACM-ICPC Programming Contest Team (involving mainlyundergrads) in the past seven years, during which the UMD teamadvanced to the finals in \emph{five} years (for which the PIreceived ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest (ICPC)Coach Award, 2017). The PI has also co-developed the University ofMaryland High School Programming competition since 2011 which promotes mathematics and computer science to high-school students both locally and globally through the public website at  http://www.cs.umd.edu/Outreach/hsContest.shtml. Several of the PI's Ph.D. students received prestigious awards (such as  Simons Award for in TCS, Google US/Canada PhD Fellowship(twice}), Ann G. Wylie Dissertation Fellowship, and UMD BestDoctoral Dissertation Awards and prestigious positions (in placessuch as Weizmann, Harvard, and Stanford) in the past.
